Title: 1923 Recap: One Calamity Down
Description:
1923 Journey the Rivers of Iron Season 2 Episode 4 Editorâ€™s Rating 4 stars * * * * Â« Previous Next Â« Previous Episode Next Episode Â» Photo: Lauren Smith/Paramount+

â€œJourney the Rivers of Ironâ€ is an especially grisly episode of a series thatâ€™s never easy on the squeamish. Alex, the most delicate Dutton, is the victim of an aggravated assault. Zane has his head strapped to a block so a jittery doctor can peel back his scalp and drill through his skull. When Lizzie eventually asks for a needle to self-administer her rabies vaccine, I hardly flinched. Iâ€™d already seen too much, and yet I hadnâ€™t seen the worst of it. Back in Bozeman, Lindy, one of Donald Whitfieldâ€™s sex workersâ€“inâ€“residence, strangles another sex worker that he was keeping as a pet.

Even watching through my fingers, itâ€™s obvious that â€œJourney the Rivers of Ironâ€ is the best episode of 1923â€™s second season so far. The Dutton family is diminished, but this week, on the eve of springtime, theyâ€™re finally recovering. Weâ€™re encouraged to believe that, come thaw, they might even be in a position to throw some punches of their own. Zane is on the mend, and Spencer is only two or three states from the ranch. Lizzie is pregnant, and Alex is en route. If they can just survive whatâ€™s left of this brutal winter, they might survive forever.

Of course, the Duttonsâ€™ greatest enemy â€” the world â€” is mounting another attack, refilling its coffers and amassing troops. Whitfield has a three-step plan for remaking Montana into a winter wonderland for the rich men who live along Chicagoâ€™s lakeshore and New Yorkers who mistake the Hudson Valleyâ€™s hills for real mountains. Step one: Develop the modern airliner. Step two: Pave a freeway through Paradise Valley at the governmentâ€™s expense. Step three: Build a resort.

â€œAmericans no longer rely upon their hands for money,â€ Whitfield explains to a room of nodding investors who are eager to see their lives in Bozeman as covetable. â€œThey use their minds.â€ This might be the exact moment when this country lost its way, at least according to the laws of Yellowstone. Hands arenâ€™t mere metonyms for the men they belong to; hands are the man. Only Banner Creighton sees the teeny-weeny problem with Whitfieldâ€™s proposal, and itâ€™s not the bit about inventing safe and speedy air travel. To build a resort in Paradise Valley, youâ€™ll have to bulldoze Jacob Dutton to the ground â€” to rip from his leathered hands not just his familyâ€™s parcel but their whole way of life.

Whitfield tells Banner to assemble an army of sheepherders who want the same land for grazing in summer, and Banner says heâ€™ll ask the miners, too. On a map, Whitfield identifies an unincorporated part of the state where they can secretly dump the bodies of Dutton men who throw themselves between the ranch and the inevitable march of progress. But can it really be so simple? Iâ€™m struggling to believe Montana will ignore the murder of the livestock commissioner and his entire family just because the killers dug the perfect ditch. Or that the Scots will be content to graze their sheep on a ski resort in the low season.

Before he pledges his men to Whitfield, Banner talks it through with Ellie. His wife has remained impressively skeptical of the mining tycoon, but the promise of a future for her family is too much to resist. She wants her son to go to university; she wants her grandsons to inherit a good name. Ellie tells her husband that if heâ€™s going to steal another manâ€™s castle, he canâ€™t leave the prince in any condition to take that castle back. I agree with her cool assessment, and yet youâ€™d really have to squint to mistake Jake Dutton for a prince right now. Itâ€™s Whitfield that Banner needs to outwit. If youâ€™re risking your life, do it to become king of the mountain, not prince of the valley.

Because, from what weâ€™ve seen in 1923, being prince of the valley is punishing. Take today as an example. Jake Dutton spends the morning assisting on meatball brain surgery so gruesome that his nephew Jack nearly hurls on several occasions. The patient on the table is the Yellowstone ranch foreman, who only finds himself in this vulnerable position in the first place because powerful men want his bossâ€™s land. Jake watches him wake up mid-surgery, in agony, with a shop-class hand drill burrowed into his head. Somehow, the surgery is successful, but thatâ€™s only Jacob Duttonâ€™s morning. â€œOne calamity down,â€ he says wryly.

In the afternoon, Jacob has to convince his nephewâ€™s wife not to leave him, which is tricky to do because Jackâ€™s fealty to his uncleâ€™s ranch is the main problem in the marriage. I actually thought Jake handled Lizzie well by establishing a third option between staying at the Yellowstone and leaving it forever; Lizzie can just visit home for a bit and return when the mercury rises. Weâ€™ll never know if Jakeâ€™s plea would have been successful, though, because the doctor confirms that Lizzie is pregnant. Thatâ€™s why sheâ€™s having such an adverse reaction to the rabies vaccine.

After that, Jacob heads to the porch to grab a few quiet minutes with his wife between debacles. They share cute, inexplicable banter about how he doesnâ€™t understand women at all and thatâ€™s somehow the bedrock of their marriage. Aunt Cara was negging long before The Pick-Up Artist.

Then, for dinner at the end of a long day, Jake probably has some broth or leftover gruel and thinks about how cold his bones are. Maybe he ruminates on the lien on his house as Cara lies next to him. Or maybe itâ€™s guilt that chases his sleep away. Look what happened to Zane. He feared he would never walk again after the beating he took, and now heâ€™s itching to fight a land war for another manâ€™s family. Maybe it would be better for everyone if Jake just walked away from the Yellowstone. Better for Zane and Alice, who could move to California, where mixed-race marriage is legal. Better for Jack and Lizzie, who could raise their baby in the relative warmth of Boston. Better for doc, who hasnâ€™t been home since before the blizzard because the Duttons make so much trouble.

And all of this? This happened on a relatively quiet day for the aging prince of Paradise Valley.

Things didnâ€™t go nearly so well for the Dutton diaspora beyond Montana state lines. After being robbed and beaten in Grand Central Station, Alex flings herself onto a moving train. She walks down the aisles of the first-class cabins with a black eye while the types of people she used to be friends with gawk. She hasnâ€™t a penny left. The worse news is that sheâ€™s sharing a bunk with other peopleâ€™s children, at least until Boston.

Spencer, meanwhile, continues his run of bad luck that momentarily disguises itself as good luck. For example, it almost seems like good luck when the Fort Worth sheriff offers him a ride to the train station, though itâ€™s quickly revealed to be bad luck when heâ€™s told to sit in the back seat like a perp. (Personally, I was surprised to learn Luca is such a squawker. Wasnâ€™t he raised on omertÃ ?)

It also seems like good luck when the sheriff offers to set Spencer free in exchange for making the booze delivery he had already promised to make, though itâ€™s bad luck when the sheriff later handcuffs him to the steering wheel. (Here, I was confused as to why the police didnâ€™t orchestrate a proper sting operation once Spencer gave them the delivery address. Why just bust down the door with no plan?)

Still, itâ€™s good luck that the sheriff leaves the key in the ignition and that Spencer is able to work himself free. And itâ€™s good luck that the Temperance Society is forcing a tarred prostitute to parade down Main Street at the exact moment Spencer goes on the run because (1) it creates an obstacle for the pursuing sheriff, and (2) it lets Spencer free a prostitute on his way home. You can take a manâ€™s ranch, but not his savior complex. Itâ€™s good luck to hop on a train headed west and bad luck to find the car already occupied by hobos that will require killing.

Ultimately, Spencer ends the episode where he started it: walking north from Fort Worth headed home to a place that wonâ€™t be home when he arrives. Because there arenâ€™t roads in the Montana that Spencer is from. Thereâ€™s no river of iron to drop his wife at a nearby station. Just wait until Spencer hears about the ski resort, and the freeway, and the airplanes. About the lien on the land thatâ€™s belonged to his family since before Montana was a state.

Teonna, Pete, and Runs His Horse are still in Texas, too. Theyâ€™re helping ranch hands drive cattle in the only 1923 story line that has any joy or vibrancy to it. Itâ€™s not a coincidence that Godâ€™s golden light shines brightest on the land in which men are still making their money with their hands. Iâ€™ve never seen Texas look prettier than it does when Taylor Sheridan shoots it. But soon, I worry, there wonâ€™t be any Texas in Texas either. The fairgrounds where the cowboys stop for lunch are plastered with Wanted posters bearing a sketch of Teonna. America is coming for her, like it came for Paradise Valley.

Itâ€™s the cycles of feast and famine that make life on the range so hard and so fulfilling weâ€™re told over and over again across Yellowstone and its spinoffs. In 1923, though, it seems like itâ€™s always famine, and famineâ€™s less fun to watch. This weekâ€™s episode offered us longer days and brighter evenings â€” the promise of story lines reaching fruition. That Spencer will make it home again; that Teonna will cross over into Mexico and find freedom; that Jack and Lizzie will have a baby. Frustratingly, it also warns us against the same longing it conjures. â€œSpring teases the senses with warm mornings and green buds of new grass and the hope of summerâ€™s bounty,â€ Elsa Dutton tells us from beyond time, where the Dutton family story is already over or maybe never-ending.

â€œThen blankets that hope in snow.â€

Title: Tony Gilroy Wonâ€™t Release â€˜Andorâ€™ Scripts for Fear of AI Training on Them: â€˜Why Help the F**king Robots?â€™
Description:
Though he enjoys building a futuristic world on screen with his hit TV series â€œAndor,â€ in real life, writer/director Tony Gilroy is trying to slow the future.

Speaking in a recent interview with Collider, Gilroy expressed his animosity toward the use of Artificial Intelligence, particularly in Hollywood, where many are training their models on screenplays whether they have the rights to them or not. For this reason, Gilroy decided to nix an initial plan to release the scripts for Season 1 as a book, similar to how â€œSuccessionâ€ and other shows have.

â€œI wanted to do it. We put it together. Itâ€™s really cool. Iâ€™ve seen it, I loved it. AI is the reason weâ€™re not,â€ said Gilroy. â€œIn the end, it would be 1,500 pages that came directly off this desk. I mean, terribly sadly, itâ€™s just too much of an X-ray and too easily absorbed. Why help the fucking robots anymore than you can? So, it was an ego thing. It was vanity that makes you want to do it, and the downside is real. So, vanity loses.â€

In writing the scripts for Season 1 and Season 2, Gilroy had more time than most to put them together. Considering how many feel the show speaks to the rise in fascism currently taking place throughout the world, many believe the show has become adept at channeling real-world conflicts into a sci-fi allegory, but Gilroy doesnâ€™t view his work as capturing the moment.

â€œNo one was working on the show with a newspaper at any point in time. We write so far in advance,â€ he told Collider. â€œIâ€™ve said this before: Iâ€™ve been a student of history, as an amateur, a dinner table historian all this time, and itâ€™s nothing but revolutions and uprisings and people being swept up into events that they werenâ€™t ready for and people assuming heroic roles that they had never anticipated.â€

Showrunner Gilroy isnâ€™t the only writer working on â€œAndor,â€ of course. Though most writersâ€™ rooms work together to shape a season of television, Gilroy prefers to let his staff loose to follow their own voices.

â€œThe writers on the show and myself, itâ€™s a pretty fancy bunch of writers, really, in a way. Everybodyâ€™s very experienced,â€ Gilroy said. â€œWe only get together for five or six days in the beginning to talk about the story, and then we kind of go, and they do their thing, and then they go away. But I always have them as a reference to call upon.â€

Title: Ed Lachman Calls Out Contemporary Cinematography: â€˜Everythingâ€™s Mushâ€™
Description:
Earning his first ASC award for â€œMariaâ€ last month, it seems cinematographer Ed Lachman now feels emboldened to bemoan current trends in film imagery. Though most movies no longer shoot on traditional film stock, many still seek out the grainy appeal in the final edit, a fact Lachman has come to detest. Still prone to work with film, as he did on Pablo LarraÃ­nâ€™s â€œMaria,â€ he also knows the challenges of processing that film by digital means.

Speaking with fellow DP Roger Deakins during a recent episode of the â€œTeam Deakinsâ€ podcast, Lachman explained how he prefers to use â€œcolor temperature and gelsâ€ in-camera to replicate film when working with digital, but most others only manipulate the image in post.

â€œThis whole idea of shooting wide open, with no depth of field, so everythingâ€™s mush in the front or the back, they think that gives them the film look,â€ said Lachman. â€œI donâ€™t, I think it looks more digital when they do that. It drives me crazy.â€

While Lachman believes many recent films fall into this category, there was one in particular from last year that particularly irked him.

â€œI donâ€™t want to mention other films, but I will. â€˜Babygirl, right?â€™ You see the wide shot, you see everything, and then every time they go into the medium shots or the close-ups, the background is totally knocked out,â€ Lachman told Deakins. â€œSo every scene looks the same. Itâ€™s like the environment, the architecture is part of the image.â€

Deakins went on to echo Lachmanâ€™s sentiments and really put the blame on how anamorphic lenses tend to wash out certain elements of an image.

â€œYou want the character to feel theyâ€™re in a space, and you want that space to register,â€ he said. â€œAnd I think, yeah, what youâ€™re saying, anamorphic, youâ€™re often isolating the character in a kind of sea of mist.â€

Lachman previously spoke to IndieWireâ€™s Jim Hemphill back in November upon the release of â€œMaria,â€ where he talked about color in the film and how it was used for both depth and to communicate how the environment reflects the mood of the central character.

â€œIâ€™ve always used color not purely as a decorative means, but as a psychological means,â€ Lachman said. â€œI always think of warm and cool colors, and how they interact. So her apartment has the warmth of a nest, like sheâ€™s hiding from the world outside, but then itâ€™s invaded by cooler colors like green. Generally, people donâ€™t like green â€” they donâ€™t think it looks good on flesh tones.â€

Lachmanâ€™s work on â€œMariaâ€ was nominated for Best Cinematography at the 97th Academy Awards, but lost to â€œThe Brutalist,â€ which shot partially in VistaVision.

Title: Jason Isbell Is Alone Again, Preternaturally, on a Superb Solo Acoustic Tour: Concert Review
Description:
â€œIâ€™ve grown tired of traveling alone,â€ Jason Isbell once sang, in a number that remains a favorite for fans in a lonesome mood. But thatâ€™s one of his old songs that means something different today. Heâ€™s traveling alone and loving it, at least in the sense that he is hitting the road as a solo artist for a first-time national acoustic tour, reflecting the formal aloneness of his just-released album â€œFoxes in the Snow.â€ Or maybe the reflection goes the other way: Isbell has suggested that he was booking the tour dates first last year and the idea of recording a full record with no band was an outgrowth of that impulse. Whichever came first, the chicken or the egg, the album and tour arriving in tandem are making for a terrific chicken-omelette dinner.

Playing a mid-tour show at Oaklandâ€™s Calvin Simmons Theatre (a juke joint as high-class as L.A.â€™s Walt Disney Concert Hall, where he also played this weekend), Isbell mentioned how he is coincidentally sharing a circuit with some musician friends right now, even if they, too, are more or less traveling alone. â€œI appreciate you guys not going to Sacramento to see Dave and Gil this evening, because I know that Gillian Welch and David Rawlings are basically at the same places that Iâ€™m at on this tour,â€ he told the Oakland crowd. â€œWeâ€™re going back and forth. We were texting before the show because I love them, theyâ€™re my favorite, and it struck us that you people love a flat-picked guitar out here. I think itâ€™s because itâ€™s hard to carry a whole bunch of gear when the towns are real far apart. â€¦ I have this theory that the guitar is the best instrument of all the instruments. I think itâ€™s because you can carry it with you and still play a full chord,â€ he noted â€” throwing in a joke about the challenge of accompanying yourself singing â€œWonderwallâ€ on the flute at a party.

Popular on Variety

The most obvious point of reference for the â€œFoxes in the Snowâ€ album has been Bruce Springsteenâ€™s completely solo â€œNebraska,â€ and itâ€™s apt, as far as thinking about making a virtue out of starkness on the edge of town. One difference is that some Springsteen fans still, to this day, debate whether his record would have worked better as an E Street album and hunger to hear the scrapped band tracks released from the vaults. Itâ€™s possible there are some Isbell fans whoâ€™ll put their imaginations to work imagining how â€œFoxesâ€ would have sounded as a band record, too â€” and possibly weâ€™ll find out if these songs turn up on his next tour with the 400 Unit â€”but his new album doesnâ€™t work as well as it does just because itâ€™s a mood piece. Itâ€™s true that the transparently autobiographical nature of most of the songs, at a time when people are taking an extra interest in Isbellâ€™s personal life, lends itself to the stripped-down format. But unlike the Springsteen record of yore, there is a level of acoustic guitar virtuosity here that is a big part of the appeal.

In other words, Isbell wasnâ€™t lying, or exaggerating, with his half-joking aside about audiences loving a flat-picked guitar. You may think youâ€™re coming for the â€œdivorce album,â€ or the newly minted love songs, with someone who is as much a master of personal lyricism as Isbell is. But whether youâ€™re as cognizant of his tastefully subtle acoustic guitar shredding as you are of his songwriting, itâ€™s true, instinctively, what they say: Every girl crazy â€˜bout a sharp-picked Martin.

Isbellâ€™s solo shows on this tour are coming in at what â€œSuccessionâ€ fans might call a â€œtight 90.â€ Heâ€™s been doing eight of the new albumâ€™s 11 songs just about every night (abeit not always the same eight), and then bolstering those with 10 more selections from the catalogâ€¦ making for a satisfying hour-and-a-half that you might wish was just a little longer, if you harbor the desire, as diehards will, to find out what every band song sounds like in this format. Setlists passed along from previous stops along the way indicate that thereâ€™s a real lottery as to which oldies youâ€™ll get on any given night. In Oakland, he opened the show with the rueful rocker â€œOverseasâ€ and closed the main portion of the set with the tender â€œSomething to Loveâ€; these are songs that donâ€™t even show up in his performances most nights. But Isbell likes playing roulette with key setlist slots that might be set in stone for most other touring acts.

Isbell went into storytelling mode for a bare handful of the songs, albeit not the most personal ones. If one case, he made it crystal-clear he is not always in memoir mode, suggesting that some listeners donâ€™t believe that no matter how obvious the hints. Following â€œThe Life You Chose,â€ he noted, â€œA lot of times people think that if you write a song and you say â€˜Iâ€™ or â€˜me,â€™ then everything in that song happened to you. For that last one, I tried to make it pretty obvious that thatâ€™s not me in their song. And still people will ask those questions, and sometimes I just hold up my fingers.â€ (In other words, â€œLost three fingers to a faulty tool / Settled out of court, Iâ€™m no oneâ€™s foolâ€ may have been a giveaway.)

After singing â€œElephant,â€ his famously harrowing song about being partnered with a woman dying of terminal cancer, he said that â€œthe first time I played that song, people were upset. You know, everybody got really quiet. Nobody clapped or anything.â€ Finally, he said, â€œThis one guy in the back of the crowd yells out, â€˜Play a sad song.'â€

Well, after playing â€œElephantâ€ at this particular show, Isbell did play a damned sad song, although itâ€™s debatable whether it was sadder than the one that came before. Next up for him was â€œGravelweed,â€ one of several tracks from the new record that seem to deal quite outrightly with a recent divorce that has been a subject of endless fan speculation. Isbell was not about to give this one a spoken introduction or outro, nor did he offer any annotation for the similarly biting â€œTrue Believer,â€ which closed the show. At least when it came to explaining any of the most confessional new material, which tends to come close to being self-explanatory, Isbell was content to let the subjects of his real-life split or subsequent love be the elephants in the room.

But Isbell fans are the type that like to read between the lines anyway, and they werenâ€™t likely to feel like the singer-songwriter was in avoidance mode, not in a show in which he opened with one number about a separation (â€œOverseasâ€) and closed the encore portion with another (â€œTrue Believerâ€). It says something about how loaded some of those new songs about his split are â€” in an album that has been compared not just to â€œNebraska,â€ but to â€œBlood on the Tracksâ€ â€” that they are right in competition with â€œElephantâ€ and â€œLive Oakâ€ â€” an actual murder ballad! â€” for the title of heaviest song of the night.

This is a mostly light-spirited show, nonetheless, despite those weighty anchor songs. Thatâ€™s partly due to the jocularity of the handful of stories he tells. And itâ€™s partly due to how â€œFoxes in the Snowâ€ has several extremely romantic songs, seemingly inspired by new love in Isbellâ€™s life. (As far as the old love songs that have different meanings now, to quote â€œGravelweed,â€ signature song â€œCover Me Upâ€ was not on the playlist on this particular night, although â€œIf We Were Vampiresâ€ remains a staple.) â€œGood While It Lasted,â€ â€œRide to Robertâ€™sâ€ and the title track of â€œFoxes in the Snowâ€ all stood as rare and fresh examples of how Isbell can write a great crush song when he sets his mind to it. Regardless of how much of his personal goings-on you read into these freshly penned numbers, they are ebullient set-lifters that came just in time, deliberately or coincidently, to ensure that his first solo tour doesnâ€™t get bogged down in breakups or missing digits.

There is one moony love song from the new album he did some explaining about â€¦ because itâ€™s not about him. Although â€œWind Behind the Rainâ€ was identified in some album reviews (including ours) as a lovestruck paean to his new partner, Isbell explained its exegesis here: â€œMy little brother got married a few months ago, and his fiance came up to me and saidâ€¦ â€˜Will you write a song for our wedding?â€™ I said, â€˜That is a bold request, so yes, Iâ€™ll do it.â€™ And oh my Godâ€¦ I have played in front of all kinds of folks and not been as nervous as I was standing up for their first dance with a guitar with this song taped to the microphone stand on a piece of notebook paper, wearing a cheap suit.â€ Isbell has not lacked for songs before that at least carried the romantic intensity of a wedding song, but now heâ€™s got one that doesnâ€™t mention vampirism or staying in bed for a week, so it may move quickly up the list of his nuptials-ready numbers.

Even if youâ€™re a fan of the 400 Unit sound, as presumably every extant devotee of his is, this solo show felt like optimal Isbell, at least in the moment, with the clarity of music and lyrics that the honed-down, zoned-in solo format allowed. It seems unlikely that heâ€™ll stay in this mode indefinitely, though. So one question is, will these new songs translate well to him going electric again? The 8-bill augurs for a favorable outcome, there; the chorus hooks of â€œEileenâ€ and â€œGravelweed,â€ especially, are too strong not to be heard loud and clear over the blare of a band. But this probably fleeting solo turn is something fans will remember as good while it lasted, to say the least.

Title: Kristin Cavallari's $8.9M Nashville Home Under Contract
